canonical_explanation.text:
Mineral nutrition deals with the study of essential mineral elements required by plants for their normal growth and development. Plants obtain carbon, hydrogen and oxygen from CO2 and water, while other elements are absorbed as mineral ions from the soil solution. Hydroponics, the technique of growing plants in a defined nutrient solution without soil, has been instrumental in identifying these essential elements.

Arnon and Stout (1939) proposed criteria for essentiality: the element must be absolutely necessary for normal growth, its requirement must be specific and not replaceable, and it must be directly involved in plant metabolism. Based on the quantity required, essential elements are classified as macronutrients (needed in large amounts, e.g., N, P, K, Ca, Mg, S) and micronutrients (needed in trace amounts, e.g., Fe, Mn, Cu, Zn, B, Mo, Cl, Ni). Deficiency of any essential element leads to characteristic symptoms such as chlorosis, necrosis, stunted growth or inhibition of cell division. Toxicity occurs when any mineral ion concentration exceeds the optimal level. Nitrogen metabolism is of special significance as nitrogen is a major constituent of proteins, nucleic acids and other biomolecules. The nitrogen cycle involves processes like nitrogen fixation (biological and industrial), ammonification, nitrification and denitrification. Biological nitrogen fixation is carried out by free-living organisms (Azotobacter, Clostridium) and symbiotic bacteria (Rhizobium in root nodules of legumes). The enzyme nitrogenase catalyses the reduction of atmospheric N2 to NH3, and leg-haemoglobin maintains the anaerobic conditions required for nitrogenase activity.
rules: An essential element must satisfy all three criteria of Arnon and Stout: absolutely necessary, specific and irreplaceable, and directly involved in metabolism.
Macronutrients (C, H, O, N, P, K, Ca, Mg, S) are required in concentrations of 1 to 10 mg per gram of dry matter or more.
Micronutrients (Fe, Mn, Cu, Zn, B, Mo, Cl, Ni) are required in concentrations of less than 0.1 mg per gram of dry matter.
Nitrogen is a constituent of proteins, nucleic acids, chlorophyll and vitamins; phosphorus is a component of nucleic acids, ATP and cell membranes.
Chlorosis (loss of chlorophyll leading to yellowing of leaves) is caused by deficiency of N, K, Mg, S, Fe, Mn, Zn or Mo.
Necrosis (death of tissue) occurs due to deficiency of Ca, Mg, Cu or K.
Hydroponics allows precise study of mineral requirements by growing plants in defined nutrient solutions.
Biological nitrogen fixation is catalysed by the enzyme nitrogenase, which requires anaerobic conditions provided by leg-haemoglobin in root nodules.
The nitrogen cycle includes nitrogen fixation, ammonification, nitrification (by Nitrosomonas and Nitrobacter) and denitrification (by Pseudomonas).
Rhizobium forms symbiotic association with roots of leguminous plants, forming root nodules for nitrogen fixation.
Toxicity of any mineral element inhibits uptake of other elements and may cause deficiency symptoms of the latter.
Molybdenum is a component of nitrogenase and is essential for nitrogen fixation; zinc activates the enzyme carboxylase.

questions.question_text: Who proposed the criteria for essentiality of mineral elements in plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Arnon and Stout (1939) proposed the criteria for essentiality of mineral elements. An element is essential if it is absolutely necessary for normal growth, its requirement is specific and irreplaceable, and it is directly involved in plant metabolism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Julius von Sachs developed the technique of hydroponics but did not define essentiality criteria. Knop improved nutrient solutions. Priestley is known for discovery of oxygen.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is NOT a criterion for essentiality of a mineral element as per Arnon and Stout?

options.text: The element must be absolutely necessary for supporting normal growth and reproduction.
The requirement of the element must be specific and not replaceable by another element.
The element must be required in large quantities for plant growth.
The element must be directly involved in the metabolism of the plant.

questions.explanation_correct: The three criteria of essentiality are: absolute necessity for normal growth, specificity (not replaceable), and direct involvement in metabolism. The quantity required is not a criterion for essentiality — both macronutrients and micronutrients are essential.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Options A, B and D are the three correct criteria proposed by Arnon and Stout for determining whether a mineral element is essential.

questions.question_text: The technique of growing plants in a defined mineral nutrient solution without soil is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Hydroponics is the technique of growing plants in a defined nutrient solution in the complete absence of soil. It was developed by Julius von Sachs and has been essential for identifying essential mineral elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Aeroponics involves growing plants with roots suspended in air and misted with nutrients. Tissue culture involves growing cells/tissues in artificial media. Vermiculture is the use of earthworms for composting.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a macronutrient?
questions.explanation_correct: Phosphorus is a macronutrient required by plants in relatively large amounts. It is a component of nucleic acids, ATP, phospholipids and coenzymes. The macronutrients are C, H, O, N, P, K, Ca, Mg and S.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zinc, manganese and copper are micronutrients required in very small amounts (less than 0.1 mg per gram of dry matter).

questions.question_text: A plant requires a mineral element in concentrations of 0.05 mg per gram of dry matter. This element is most likely classified as:
questions.explanation_correct: Micronutrients are elements required in concentrations of less than 0.1 mg per gram of dry matter. Since 0.05 mg/g is below 0.1 mg/g, this element would be classified as a micronutrient.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Macronutrients are required in concentrations of 1 to 10 mg per gram or more. The element is essential (meets essentiality criteria) so it is not merely beneficial or non-essential.

questions.question_text: Magnesium is an essential macronutrient because it:

options.text: is a component of the cell wall.
is a constituent of chlorophyll and activates enzymes of respiration and photosynthesis.
is required for electron transport only.
helps in the opening and closing of stomata.

questions.explanation_correct: Magnesium is a constituent of the chlorophyll molecule (it occupies the centre of the porphyrin ring) and also activates enzymes involved in respiration, photosynthesis and nucleic acid synthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calcium (not Mg) is a major component of the cell wall middle lamella. Potassium (not Mg) helps in stomatal opening and closing. Mg is involved in more than just electron transport.

questions.question_text: Which micronutrient is a component of the enzymes nitrogenase and nitrate reductase?
questions.explanation_correct: Molybdenum (Mo) is a component of several enzymes including nitrogenase (involved in biological nitrogen fixation) and nitrate reductase (involved in reduction of nitrate to nitrite in plants).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Zinc activates carboxylase and is needed for auxin synthesis. Iron is needed for ferredoxin and cytochromes. Boron is required for uptake and utilisation of calcium, pollen germination and cell elongation.

questions.question_text: A student sets up a hydroponic experiment omitting potassium from the nutrient solution. Which of the following roles of potassium would be directly affected?

options.text: Maintenance of turgidity, opening and closing of stomata, and activation of enzymes
Formation of the middle lamella of the cell wall
Component of nucleic acids and ATP

questions.explanation_correct: Potassium plays a key role in maintaining the turgidity of cells, stomatal movement (opening and closing), and activation of several enzymes. Its deficiency leads to inhibition of protein synthesis and premature death of leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Chlorophyll synthesis requires Mg and Fe. Middle lamella formation requires Ca. Nucleic acids and ATP contain P, not K.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about essential mineral elements:
(i) Manganese activates enzymes involved in photolysis of water during photosynthesis.
(ii) Zinc is required for synthesis of auxin.
(iii) Boron is required for uptake and utilisation of Ca2+, pollen germination and cell elongation.
(iv) Copper is a component of chlorophyll.
Which of the above statements are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii) and (iii) are correct. Mn activates enzymes in photolysis of water, Zn is needed for auxin synthesis, and B is required for Ca uptake, pollen germination and cell elongation. Statement (iv) is incorrect — magnesium (not copper) is a component of chlorophyll.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Copper is involved in certain redox reactions and is a component of plastocyanin, but it is NOT a component of the chlorophyll molecule. Magnesium is the metal ion present in chlorophyll.

questions.question_text:
Match the mineral element with its primary role:
(a) Calcium - (i) Component of ferredoxin
(b) Iron - (ii) Activates carboxylase
(c) Zinc - (iii) Required in middle lamella formation
(d) Sulphur - (iv) Component of cysteine and methionine
Select the correct option:
questions.explanation_correct: Calcium is used in the formation of the middle lamella (as calcium pectate). Iron is a component of ferredoxin and cytochromes. Zinc activates carboxylase and is needed for auxin synthesis. Sulphur is a component of amino acids cysteine and methionine, and coenzymes like CoA.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other combinations do not correctly pair the mineral elements with their primary roles as described in NCERT.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Hydroponics is widely used to study mineral nutrition in plants.
Reason (R): In hydroponics, the composition of the nutrient solution can be precisely controlled and individual elements can be added or removed.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.

questions.explanation_correct: Both the assertion and reason are true. Hydroponics allows scientists to grow plants in a defined nutrient solution where each element can be precisely controlled, added or omitted, making it an ideal technique for studying the essentiality and roles of individual mineral elements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason correctly explains why hydroponics is useful for mineral nutrition studies — the ability to control composition precisely is the key advantage.

questions.question_text: How many essential mineral elements have been identified for plant growth?
questions.explanation_correct: Seventeen essential elements have been identified as essential for most plants. These include 9 macronutrients (C, H, O, N, P, K, Ca, Mg, S) and 8 micronutrients (Fe, Mn, Cu, Zn, B, Mo, Cl, Ni).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The number is 17, not 12, 15 or 21. Some additional elements may be beneficial for specific plants but 17 are considered universally essential.

questions.question_text: Nitrogen is absorbed by plants primarily in which forms?
questions.explanation_correct: Plants absorb nitrogen mainly as nitrate ions (NO3-) and ammonium ions (NH4+) from the soil solution. Most plants preferentially absorb nitrate, which is then reduced to ammonia inside the plant for amino acid synthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Plants cannot directly absorb atmospheric N2 (only nitrogen-fixing organisms can). NH3, NO2-, N2O, NO and NO2 are not the primary forms absorbed by plant roots from soil.

questions.question_text: Which element is a constituent of every amino acid in plants?
questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogen is a constituent of every amino acid (present in the amino group -NH2). It is also found in proteins, nucleic acids, chlorophyll and many other biomolecules, making it the most critical mineral element for plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Phosphorus is found in nucleic acids and ATP but not in every amino acid. Potassium and calcium are important cations but are not constituents of amino acids.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following elements can be categorised as both structural and functional in plants?
(i) Nitrogen
(ii) Phosphorus
(iii) Potassium
(iv) Calcium
questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogen is a structural component of proteins and nucleic acids and also has functional roles in enzyme activity. Phosphorus is part of nucleic acids, ATP and membranes (structural) and involved in energy transfer (functional). Calcium is a structural component of the cell wall (middle lamella) and also functions in signalling. Potassium, however, is primarily functional (enzyme activation, osmoregulation) and is not a structural component of organic molecules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Potassium does not form part of any structural organic molecule in plants; it exists as an ion and functions mainly in enzyme activation and osmotic regulation.

questions.question_text: Which mineral element is required for the activation of the enzyme RuBisCO?
questions.explanation_correct: Magnesium is required as a cofactor for the activation of RuBisCO (Ribulose bisphosphate carboxylase oxygenase), the most abundant enzyme involved in carbon fixation during photosynthesis.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Manganese is involved in photolysis of water. Molybdenum is part of nitrogenase and nitrate reductase. Iron is a component of ferredoxin and cytochromes.

questions.question_text: Chlorosis refers to:

options.text: death of tissue, particularly leaf tissue.
loss of chlorophyll leading to yellowing of leaves.
inhibition of cell division at the shoot apex.

questions.explanation_correct: Chlorosis is the loss of chlorophyll leading to yellowing of leaves. It is a common deficiency symptom caused by lack of elements like N, K, Mg, S, Fe, Mn, Zn or Mo, all of which are involved in chlorophyll synthesis or function.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Death of tissue is called necrosis, not chlorosis. Delay in flowering and inhibition of cell division are other deficiency symptoms but they are not termed chlorosis.

questions.question_text: Necrosis (death of tissue) in plants can be caused by the deficiency of:
questions.explanation_correct: Necrosis (death of cells or tissues) can result from the deficiency of Ca, Mg, Cu and K. These elements are involved in maintaining membrane integrity and enzyme function, and their absence leads to tissue death.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Deficiency of N and S causes chlorosis, not typically necrosis. Boron deficiency causes stunted growth and Cl deficiency causes wilting. Fe and Mo deficiency causes chlorosis.

questions.question_text: Deficiency symptoms of mineral elements tend to appear first in older leaves when the element is:

options.text: immobile in the plant, such as calcium.
actively mobilised from older tissues to younger tissues.

questions.explanation_correct: When an element is mobile (e.g., N, P, K, Mg), the plant translocates it from older, mature leaves to younger, actively growing regions. Hence, deficiency symptoms appear first in the older leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Immobile elements like Ca show deficiency symptoms first in young leaves. Whether the element is a micro or macronutrient, or involved in cell wall formation, does not determine where symptoms first appear — mobility does.

questions.question_text: A plant shows interveinal chlorosis in young leaves. Which element is most likely deficient?
questions.explanation_correct: Iron deficiency causes interveinal chlorosis (yellowing between veins while veins remain green) in young leaves because iron is relatively immobile in the plant and is not easily translocated from older to younger leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrogen deficiency causes general chlorosis first in older leaves (N is mobile). Potassium deficiency shows scorched leaf tips. Phosphorus deficiency causes purplish colouration.

questions.question_text: Whiptail disease in cauliflower is caused by the deficiency of:
questions.explanation_correct: Whiptail disease in cauliflower is caused by deficiency of molybdenum. The leaves become narrow, distorted and whip-like. Molybdenum is essential for nitrate reductase activity and nitrogen metabolism.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Boron deficiency causes browning of cauliflower curd (brown heart). Zinc deficiency causes little leaf disease. Manganese deficiency causes grey spot in oats but not whiptail in cauliflower.

questions.question_text: Deficiency of calcium in plants leads to which of the following symptoms?

options.text: Stunted growth and deformed young leaves due to improper cell wall formation

questions.explanation_correct: Calcium is an immobile element required for cell wall formation (middle lamella as calcium pectate) and cell membrane integrity. Its deficiency causes stunted growth, deformation of young leaves, and necrosis of meristematic regions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Yellowing of older leaves is due to N or Mg deficiency. Purplish stems indicate P deficiency. Delayed seed germination is not a characteristic Ca deficiency symptom.

questions.question_text: Toxicity of a mineral element in plants generally:

options.text: has no effect on other mineral elements.
inhibits the uptake of other elements, causing their deficiency.
leads to thickening of the cell wall.

questions.explanation_correct: Toxicity of any mineral ion in excess concentration inhibits the uptake of other elements and can cause deficiency symptoms of those elements. For example, excess manganese can induce iron, magnesium or calcium deficiency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Mineral toxicity does interfere with uptake of other elements. It does not increase photosynthesis or cause cell wall thickening.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Deficiency of nitrogen causes chlorosis first in older leaves.
Reason (R): Nitrogen is a mobile element that is readily translocated from older to younger leaves.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.

questions.explanation_correct: Both assertion and reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Nitrogen is a mobile element — when deficient, it is mobilised from older leaves to younger, growing tissues. Hence, older leaves show chlorosis first.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is true and it is the correct explanation for why N deficiency symptoms appear first in older leaves.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following deficiency symptoms:
(i) Die-back of shoot tips — deficiency of Cu and K
(ii) Stunted root growth — deficiency of Ca
(iii) Little leaf disease — deficiency of Zn
(iv) Chlorosis of young leaves — deficiency of N
Which of the above are correctly matched?
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii) and (iii) are correct. Die-back of shoot tips occurs due to Cu and K deficiency. Stunted root growth occurs due to Ca deficiency (Ca is needed for cell wall and root development). Little leaf disease is caused by Zn deficiency. Statement (iv) is incorrect — N deficiency causes chlorosis of older (not young) leaves, since N is a mobile element.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrogen is a mobile element, so its deficiency symptoms (chlorosis) appear first in older leaves, not young leaves. This makes statement (iv) incorrect.

questions.question_text: Manganese toxicity in plants results in the appearance of:

options.text: brown spots surrounded by chlorotic veins.

questions.explanation_correct: Manganese toxicity causes the appearance of brown spots surrounded by chlorotic veins on leaves. Excess manganese also inhibits the uptake of iron, magnesium and calcium, leading to their deficiency symptoms.
questions.explanation_incorrect: White spots, blue-green colouration and upward curling of leaf margins are not characteristic symptoms of manganese toxicity.

questions.question_text: Khaira disease of rice is caused by the deficiency of:
questions.explanation_correct: Khaira disease of rice is caused by the deficiency of zinc. Zinc is essential for the synthesis of auxin (tryptophan is a precursor of IAA) and its deficiency leads to stunted growth and small leaves.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron deficiency causes interveinal chlorosis. Boron deficiency affects pollen germination and cell elongation. Copper deficiency causes die-back of shoot tips.

questions.question_text: A plant shows purple colouration in its stems and leaves. Which element is most likely deficient?
questions.explanation_correct: Phosphorus deficiency often causes the accumulation of anthocyanin pigments, leading to purple or reddish colouration of stems and leaves. P is a component of nucleic acids, ATP and phospholipids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Sulphur deficiency causes chlorosis of young leaves. Magnesium deficiency causes interveinal chlorosis of older leaves. Manganese deficiency causes chlorosis and grey spots.

questions.question_text: Which of the following elements, when deficient, causes delayed flowering and reduced seed and fruit formation?
questions.explanation_correct: Phosphorus deficiency causes delayed flowering and reduced seed and fruit formation, as P is essential for energy transfer (ATP), nucleic acid synthesis and various metabolic processes critical for reproductive growth.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Iron deficiency causes interveinal chlorosis. Chlorine deficiency causes wilting of leaf tips. Manganese deficiency causes chlorosis but does not typically delay flowering as prominently as P deficiency.

questions.question_text:
Match the deficiency disease with the deficient element:
(a) Whiptail of cauliflower - (i) Zn
(b) Khaira disease of rice - (ii) B
(c) Brown heart of turnip - (iii) Mo
(d) Die-back of citrus - (iv) Cu
Select the correct option:
questions.explanation_correct: Whiptail of cauliflower is caused by Mo deficiency. Khaira disease of rice is caused by Zn deficiency. Brown heart of turnip is caused by B (boron) deficiency. Die-back of citrus is caused by Cu (copper) deficiency.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The other combinations do not match the diseases with the correct deficient elements.

questions.question_text: The process by which atmospheric nitrogen is converted into ammonia by soil bacteria is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Biological nitrogen fixation is the process by which atmospheric nitrogen (N2) is reduced to ammonia (NH3) by certain prokaryotic organisms (e.g., Rhizobium, Azotobacter) using the enzyme nitrogenase.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ammonification is the conversion of organic nitrogen to ammonia during decomposition. Nitrification converts ammonia to nitrite and then nitrate. Denitrification reduces nitrate to gaseous nitrogen.

questions.question_text: Which enzyme catalyses the reduction of atmospheric nitrogen to ammonia?
questions.explanation_correct: Nitrogenase is the enzyme that catalyses the reduction of atmospheric N2 to NH3 during biological nitrogen fixation. It requires anaerobic conditions and uses 16 ATP molecules per molecule of N2 fixed.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrate reductase converts nitrate to nitrite. Glutamine synthetase assimilates ammonia into glutamine. Urease breaks down urea into ammonia and CO2.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a symbiotic nitrogen-fixing bacterium?
questions.explanation_correct: Rhizobium is a symbiotic nitrogen-fixing bacterium that forms root nodules in leguminous plants. The bacteria fix atmospheric nitrogen into ammonia, which is used by the plant, and in return receive organic nutrients from the host.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Azotobacter and Clostridium are free-living nitrogen fixers. Nitrobacter is a nitrifying bacterium that oxidises nitrite to nitrate.

questions.question_text: The function of leg-haemoglobin in root nodules of legumes is to:

options.text: transport nitrogen to the host plant.
scavenge oxygen to provide anaerobic conditions for nitrogenase.

questions.explanation_correct: Leg-haemoglobin (leghemoglobin) is an oxygen-scavenging molecule found in root nodules. It protects the enzyme nitrogenase from oxygen, as nitrogenase is irreversibly inactivated by O2. Leg-haemoglobin creates the anaerobic conditions necessary for nitrogen fixation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Leg-haemoglobin does not transport nitrogen, fix nitrogen directly, or supply iron. Its sole function is to maintain anaerobic conditions by binding free oxygen.

questions.question_text:
The overall equation for biological nitrogen fixation is:
N2 + 8e- + 8H+ + 16ATP → 2NH3 + H2 + 16ADP + 16Pi
This equation indicates that nitrogen fixation:

options.text: is an exergonic process that releases energy.
requires a large input of energy (16 ATP per N2 molecule).
produces water as the only by-product.

questions.explanation_correct: The equation shows that 16 molecules of ATP are consumed per molecule of N2 fixed, indicating that biological nitrogen fixation is highly energy-demanding. The triple bond in N2 is very stable and requires significant energy to break.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The process consumes ATP, so it is endergonic. It requires strictly anaerobic conditions (not aerobic). H2 is produced as a by-product, not water.

questions.question_text: Which of the following bacteria is involved in the process of nitrification?
questions.explanation_correct: Nitrification is carried out in two steps: Nitrosomonas oxidises ammonia to nitrite (NH3 → NO2-), and Nitrobacter oxidises nitrite to nitrate (NO2- → NO3-). Both are chemoautotrophic nitrifying bacteria.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rhizobium and Frankia are nitrogen fixers. Pseudomonas and Thiobacillus are denitrifying bacteria. Azotobacter and Clostridium are free-living nitrogen fixers.

questions.question_text: In the nitrogen cycle, the process by which soil bacteria convert nitrates back into gaseous nitrogen is called:
questions.explanation_correct: Denitrification is the process by which soil bacteria like Pseudomonas convert nitrates (NO3-) back into gaseous nitrogen (N2), returning it to the atmosphere. This process occurs under anaerobic conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrogen fixation converts N2 to NH3 (the reverse process). Ammonification converts organic N to NH3. Nitrification converts NH3 to NO3-.

questions.question_text: Ammonification is the process by which:

options.text: atmospheric N2 is converted to NH3 by bacteria.
organic nitrogen in dead organisms is converted to ammonia by decomposers.
ammonia is converted to nitrate by chemoautotrophs.
ammonia is assimilated into amino acids by plants.

questions.explanation_correct: Ammonification is the decomposition of organic nitrogen (from dead plants, animals and excretory products) into ammonia by bacteria and fungi (decomposers) in the soil. This ammonia can then be nitrified or used by plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Conversion of N2 to NH3 is nitrogen fixation. Conversion of NH3 to NO3- is nitrification. Assimilation of NH3 into amino acids is called ammonia assimilation.

questions.question_text:
Assertion (A): Nitrogenase enzyme is highly sensitive to molecular oxygen.
Reason (R): Leg-haemoglobin in root nodules has a very high affinity for oxygen and protects nitrogenase from oxidative damage.
Select the correct option:

options.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.

questions.explanation_correct: Both the assertion and the reason are true, and the reason correctly explains the assertion. Nitrogenase is irreversibly inactivated by oxygen, so leg-haemoglobin scavenges O2 in root nodules to protect the enzyme and maintain anaerobic conditions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reason is true and provides the correct explanation for the assertion. Leg-haemoglobin's high O2 affinity is precisely the mechanism that protects the oxygen-sensitive nitrogenase.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following sequences in the nitrogen cycle:
(i) N2 → NH3 (Nitrogen fixation)
(ii) NH3 → NO2- → NO3- (Nitrification)
(iii) NO3- → N2 (Denitrification)
(iv) Organic N → NH3 (Ammonification)
The correct sequence of processes that returns nitrogen from living organisms back to the atmosphere is:
questions.explanation_correct: When organisms die, their organic nitrogen is first converted to ammonia by ammonification (iv). The ammonia is then oxidised to nitrate by nitrification (ii). Finally, denitrification (iii) converts nitrate back to atmospheric N2. This completes the return of nitrogen to the atmosphere.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrogen fixation (i) is the process that brings N2 from the atmosphere into living systems, not the return process. The correct return pathway is ammonification → nitrification → denitrification.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following organisms can fix atmospheric nitrogen?
(i) Rhizobium
(ii) Azotobacter
(iii) Anabaena
(iv) Nitrobacter
questions.explanation_correct: Rhizobium (symbiotic), Azotobacter (free-living) and Anabaena (cyanobacterium, both free-living and symbiotic with Azolla) are all nitrogen-fixing organisms possessing nitrogenase. Nitrobacter is a nitrifying bacterium that oxidises nitrite to nitrate, not a nitrogen fixer.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrobacter is involved in nitrification (NO2- → NO3-), not in nitrogen fixation. It does not possess nitrogenase enzyme.

questions.question_text: In leguminous plants, the initial product of nitrogen fixation in root nodules is:
questions.explanation_correct: The initial product of biological nitrogen fixation is ammonia (NH3). Nitrogenase reduces atmospheric N2 to NH3, which is then quickly protonated to NH4+ and assimilated into organic forms like glutamate and glutamine.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrate and nitrite are products of nitrification, not nitrogen fixation. Urea is an animal excretory product, not a product of biological nitrogen fixation.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a free-living aerobic nitrogen-fixing bacterium?
questions.explanation_correct: Azotobacter is a free-living, aerobic nitrogen-fixing bacterium found in soil. It can fix atmospheric nitrogen independently without forming any symbiotic association with plants.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Clostridium is a free-living anaerobic nitrogen fixer. Rhizobium is a symbiotic nitrogen fixer (lives in root nodules of legumes). Frankia is a symbiotic nitrogen fixer (associated with non-leguminous plants like Alnus).

questions.question_text: The ammonia produced during nitrogen fixation is primarily assimilated into organic compounds through the formation of:
questions.explanation_correct: Ammonia is primarily assimilated into organic compounds through the formation of glutamate (via glutamate dehydrogenase or GS-GOGAT pathway) and glutamine (via glutamine synthetase). These amino acids then serve as nitrogen donors for synthesis of other amino acids.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While alanine, aspartate, glycine and others are amino acids formed later, the primary assimilation of ammonia occurs through glutamate and glutamine.

questions.question_text: During biological nitrogen fixation by Rhizobium, the nif genes are responsible for:

options.text: synthesis of nitrogenase and other proteins related to nitrogen fixation.

questions.explanation_correct: The nif (nitrogen fixation) genes are a set of genes found in nitrogen-fixing bacteria like Rhizobium that code for the nitrogenase enzyme complex and other proteins required for nitrogen fixation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Root hair formation is controlled by plant genes. Leg-haemoglobin is coded partly by the plant genome. Nodule senescence is a separate developmental process.

questions.question_text: Which cyanobacterium forms a symbiotic association with the water fern Azolla and fixes nitrogen?
questions.explanation_correct: Anabaena azollae is a cyanobacterium that lives in symbiotic association with the water fern Azolla. This association is used as biofertiliser in rice paddy fields as it fixes atmospheric nitrogen.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nostoc can fix nitrogen and forms associations with some plants, but the specific Azolla symbiont is Anabaena. Oscillatoria and Spirulina are not known for this particular symbiosis.

questions.question_text: The reduction of nitrate to ammonia in plants occurs through which sequence?
questions.explanation_correct: In plants, nitrate is first reduced to nitrite by nitrate reductase (in the cytoplasm) and then nitrite is reduced to ammonia by nitrite reductase (in the plastids). This two-step reduction is how plants assimilate nitrogen absorbed as nitrate.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The reduction does not occur in a single step. It does not involve N2 or N2O as intermediates — those are involved in the nitrogen cycle in soil, not in plant assimilation.

questions.question_text: A farmer notices that the older leaves of his crop plants are turning yellow while younger leaves remain green. Which of the following mineral deficiencies could explain this observation?
questions.explanation_correct: Magnesium is a mobile element, so its deficiency symptoms (chlorosis/yellowing) appear first in older leaves as the plant translocates Mg from older to younger leaves. N and K deficiencies also show similar patterns, but among the options, Mg is the correct choice.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Calcium, iron and boron are relatively immobile elements, so their deficiency symptoms appear first in young leaves, not older leaves.

questions.question_text: Which of the following pairs of elements and their roles is INCORRECTLY matched?

options.text: Nitrogen — component of proteins and nucleic acids
Phosphorus — component of ATP and cell membranes
Calcium — component of the middle lamella

questions.explanation_correct: Potassium is NOT a structural component of chlorophyll — magnesium is the metal ion present in chlorophyll. Potassium functions mainly in enzyme activation, stomatal movement and osmotic regulation.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nitrogen is indeed a component of proteins and nucleic acids. Phosphorus is a component of ATP and cell membranes (phospholipids). Calcium is a component of the middle lamella (as calcium pectate). These are all correctly matched.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following statements about nitrogen metabolism:
(i) Leg-haemoglobin is synthesised by both the plant and the bacterium.
(ii) Nitrogenase requires 16 ATP molecules for every molecule of N2 fixed.
(iii) Ammonia is the first stable product of nitrogen fixation.
(iv) Rhizobium can fix nitrogen in the free-living state.
Which of the above statements are correct?
questions.explanation_correct: Statements (i), (ii) and (iii) are correct. Leg-haemoglobin is coded partly by the plant genome (globin part) and partly by the bacterial genome (haem part). Nitrogenase uses 16 ATP per N2 molecule. Ammonia is the first stable product. Statement (iv) is incorrect — Rhizobium cannot fix nitrogen in the free-living state; it fixes nitrogen only in symbiosis within root nodules.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Rhizobium is an obligate symbiotic nitrogen fixer and cannot fix nitrogen when free-living. This distinguishes it from Azotobacter and Clostridium, which are free-living nitrogen fixers.
